title: Tesco's Dave Lewis buy shares one day after saying he was barred
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Oct 8, 2015, 18:51 BST - UK Markets closed Tesco's Dave Lewis buy shares one day after saying he was barred By Ashley Armstrong | Telegraph – 18 minutes ago 2.73 +0.05 
Tesco (Xetra: 852647 - news ) chief executive Dave Lewis buys 99,950 shares in the supermarket despite saying one day earlier that the board had barred themselves from doing so 
Tesco’s chief executive, Dave Lewis, has bought his first shares in the supermarket - just a day after saying that the board had barred themselves from trading in the stock because they had too much inside information. 
Stock market filings showed Mr Lewis has bought 99,950 shares at 200.1p each, worth around £199,900. 
Tesco chairman John Allan spent £99,746 buying 50,891 shares at 196.5p each while finance boss Allan Stewart bought 50,000 shares at 202.4p each, spending a total of £101,000. 
Mr Lewis and Mr Stewart had previously been chastised for their lack of investment in the supermarket which corporate governance groups said showed the executives were unwilling to back Tesco’s turnaround with their own money. 
On Wednesday, Mr Lewis used Tesco’s interim results as an opportunity to respond to the criticism and said that the reason he had not bought shares was because the board had barred themselves from trading in the stock because they held so much “inside information”. 
The share purchases less than 24 hours later by him and his fellow directors could raise eyebrows about Mr Lewis and the commitment he pledged on Wednesday to “transparency”. 
Mr Lewis, who took the helm at Tesco last September, said the criticism of his not buying shares had been unfair. 
He said that given the “optionality of our asset sales, we had quite a lot of inside information about what may or may not happen. 
Added to that we are in the middle of a regulatory review. Given we have all of this ongoing, we have excluded ourselves from trading in the shares... it would not be appropriate”. 
Mr Lewis said he was included in a list of board members who would “definitely” like to invest but had barred themselves from doing so. 
Tesco said on Wednesday that its “portfolio reshaping” programme had concluded and it would keep data analytics business Dunnhumby after a failed auction. Last month, Tesco agreed the £4.2bn sale of its South Korean business to an Asian private equity firm MBK . 
The company has declined to comment on an ongoing investigation by the Serious Fraud Office over last year’s £326m “blackhole” accounting scandal although there have been reports that it was preparing to enter into a “plea bargain” with the authority.
